thread.title: There is a ‘dark side’ to the ETF boom: study
thread.title_full: There is a ‘dark side’ to the ETF boom: study - MarketWatch

author: By     Victor Reklaitis
title: There is a ‘dark side’ to the ETF boom: study
text:
A new study has provided more ammunition to market watchers who see danger in the growing popularity of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and other index-tracking funds.
Greater usage of ETFs “can lead to higher trading costs” and “lower benefits from information acquisition,” says the study by researchers at three business schools titled “Is There a Dark Side to Exchange Traded Funds (ETFs)?”
Moreover, there has been an increase in stocks moving more in step with one another, the study’s authors say.
How are trading costs higher? ETFs have diverted many investors from directly buying and selling certain stocks, leading to less competition for these stocks and increased trading costs for everyone, as measured by the bid-ask spread. That is how Simon Constable describes one of the study’s key findings in The Wall Street Journal.
And “lower benefits from information acquisition” refers to analyst coverage of a stock decreasing as ownership of that stock by ETFs rises. The study’s authors have found that is happening, and they lament that analysts have lower incentives to cover individual stocks. Wall Street’s company-specific research in general has been useful for investors, they say.
Another reading of the study comes from the Financial Times, which says the ability of active fund managers to pick winning stocks is being eroded by the ETF industry’s huge growth . That sounds like a potentially vicious circle for active managers. Investors choose passive funds over those run by stock pickers, making life more difficult for the stock pickers and possibly leading to even more money exiting their ailing actively managed funds.
But the study already has its skeptics.
Current conditions are “no more or less challenging for active managers” than they have been since 1991, Vanguard’s Jim Rowley told the FT. Rowley is a senior analyst in indexing pioneer Vanguard’s investment strategy group.
The study sounds a similar note as a Morningstar researcher did in an April column about a possible “dark side” to Vanguard’s success . And by emphasizing that stocks could be increasingly moving together, the study is repeating one common fear about ETFs .
A version of the new study dated July 26 has been published on the Social Science Research Network’s website . The study’s authors are from the Arison School of Business in Israel and Stanford University’s and UCLA’s business schools.
